title: Getting started with ausbushfire
text: ausbushfire provides two teaching datasets Shiny app interactively explore meteorological context relevant Australian bushfires. climate_data: monthly global temperature anomalies (°C). fwi_synthetic: monthly Fire Weather Index (FWI) (synthetic/demo). also provides small helper functions quick analysis: calculate_statistics() — descriptive statistics within year range annual_trends() — yearly mean/max/min time series extreme_events() — yearly counts/frequency beyond threshold package ships interactive app launched run_ausbushfire_app().
code: library(ausbushfire) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(ggplot2)

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
text: Key columns: Year (integer), Month (abbrev: Jan–Dec), Date (mid-month Date) Quarter (“Q1”–“Q4”) Temperature_Anomaly (°C)
code: data("climate_data", package = "ausbushfire") dplyr::glimpse(climate_data) #> Rows: 1,748 #> Columns: 5 #> $ Year                <int> 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 1880, 18… #> $ Month               <fct> Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May, Jun, Jul, Aug, Sep, Oct, … #> $ Temperature_Anomaly <dbl> -0.19, -0.25, -0.09, -0.16, -0.10, -0.21, -0.18, -… #> $ Date                <date> 1880-01-15, 1880-02-15, 1880-03-15, 1880-04-15, 1… #> $ Quarter             <chr> "Q1", "Q1", "Q1", "Q2", "Q2", "Q2", "Q3", "Q3", "Q…

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
text: Key column: FWI (numeric). Example banding: 0–5 (Low), 5–15 (Moderate), 15–30 (High), 30+ (Extreme)

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
code: # Temperature anomaly stats for 2000–2020 calculate_statistics("climate", 2000, 2020) #> # A tibble: 1 × 10 #>   Dataset Period        N N_non_missing  Mean Median    SD   Min   Max   IQR #>   <chr>   <chr>     <int>         <int> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 climate 2000-2020   252           252  0.71    0.7 0.201  0.24  1.36  0.25  # FWI stats for 2000–2020 calculate_statistics("fwi", 2000, 2020) #> # A tibble: 1 × 10 #>   Dataset Period        N N_non_missing  Mean Median    SD   Min   Max   IQR #>   <chr>   <chr>     <int>         <int> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 fwi     2000-2020   252           252  7.42   7.28  3.36     0  15.6  4.86

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
code: clim_annual <- annual_trends("climate", 2000, 2020)  ggplot(clim_annual, aes(Year, Annual_Mean)) + geom_line(linewidth = 0.9) + geom_point(size = 1.3) + labs(x = NULL, y = "Annual mean anomaly (°C)") fwi_annual <- annual_trends("fwi", 2000, 2020)  ggplot(fwi_annual, aes(Year, Annual_Mean)) + geom_line(linewidth = 0.9) + geom_point(size = 1.3) + labs(x = NULL, y = "Annual mean FWI")

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
text: Use thresholds appropriate variable. Temperature anomalies: e.g. > 1.0 °C FWI: e.g. >= 10
code: ext_clim <- extreme_events("climate", threshold = 1.0, comparator = ">",  start_year = 2000, end_year = 2020) ext_fwi  <- extreme_events("fwi",     threshold = 10,  comparator = ">=", start_year = 2000, end_year = 2020)  par(mfrow = c(1,2)) plot(ext_clim$Year, ext_clim$Extreme_Frequency, type = "b", xlab = "Year", ylab = "Frequency", main = "Anomaly > 1°C") plot(ext_fwi$Year,  ext_fwi$Extreme_Frequency,  type = "b", xlab = "Year", ylab = "Frequency", main = "FWI ≥ 10") par(mfrow = c(1,1))

title: Getting started with ausbushfire
text: can use run_ausbushfire_app() command run Shiny app. app uses package datasets (read.csv), provides interactive controls explore monthly/quarterly/yearly structure, includes brief guidance notes interpretation.

title: Global temperature anomaly dataset — climate_data
text: Monthly global temperature anomalies 1880 2025, expressed departures long-term climatological baseline (°C).

title: Global temperature anomaly dataset — climate_data
text: data frame (tibble) 5 variables: Year Integer year (1880–2025) Month Month abbreviation (Jan, Feb, ..., Dec) Temperature_Anomaly Temperature anomaly °C (numeric) Date Date (set 15th month) Quarter Quarter label character: "Q1", "Q2", "Q3", "Q4"

title: Global temperature anomaly dataset — climate_data
text: Cleaned NASA GISTEMP (e.g., GLB.Ts+dSST.csv).

title: Extreme events frequency — extreme_events
text: Count number frequency observations exceeding threshold per year selected dataset.

title: Extreme events frequency — extreme_events
code: extreme_events(   data_type = c("climate", "fwi"),   threshold,   comparator = c(">", ">=", "<", "<="),   start_year = 1900,   end_year = 2025 )

title: Extreme events frequency — extreme_events
text: data_type One "climate" "fwi". threshold Numeric threshold (e.g. 1.0 anomalies, 10 FWI). comparator Comparison operator string: one ">", ">=", "<", "<=". Defaults ">". start_year Start year (inclusive). end_year End year (inclusive).

title: Extreme events frequency — extreme_events
text: tibble columns Year, Extreme_Count, Extreme_Frequency.

title: Extreme events frequency — extreme_events
code: # Temperature anomalies > 1°C extreme_events("climate", threshold = 1.0, start_year = 2000, end_year = 2020) #> # A tibble: 21 × 3 #>     Year Extreme_Count Extreme_Frequency #>    <int>         <int>             <dbl> #>  1  2000             0             0     #>  2  2001             0             0     #>  3  2002             0             0     #>  4  2003             0             0     #>  5  2004             0             0     #>  6  2005             0             0     #>  7  2006             0             0     #>  8  2007             1             0.083 #>  9  2008             0             0     #> 10  2009             0             0     #> # ℹ 11 more rows  # FWI >= 10 (extreme) extreme_events("fwi", threshold = 10, comparator = ">=", start_year = 2000, end_year = 2020) #> # A tibble: 21 × 3 #>     Year Extreme_Count Extreme_Frequency #>    <int>         <int>             <dbl> #>  1  2000             4             0.333 #>  2  2001             4             0.333 #>  3  2002             3             0.25  #>  4  2003             4             0.333 #>  5  2004             3             0.25  #>  6  2005             2             0.167 #>  7  2006             4             0.333 #>  8  2007             2             0.167 #>  9  2008             2             0.167 #> 10  2009             3             0.25  #> # ℹ 11 more rows
